title: The Dirty Dozen
text:
The Dirty Dozen is a 1967 <a href="war%20film">war film</a> starring <a href="Lee%20Marvin">Lee Marvin</a> and featuring an ensemble supporting cast including <a href="Ernest%20Borgnine">Ernest Borgnine</a>, <a href="Charles%20Bronson">Charles Bronson</a>, <a href="Jim%20Brown">Jim Brown</a>, <a href="John%20Cassavetes">John Cassavetes</a>, <a href="George%20Kennedy">George Kennedy</a>, <a href="Robert%20Ryan">Robert Ryan</a>, <a href="Telly%20Savalas">Telly Savalas</a>, <a href="Robert%20Webber">Robert Webber</a> and <a href="Donald%20Sutherland">Donald Sutherland</a>.
The film, which was directed by <a href="Robert%20Aldrich">Robert Aldrich</a>, was filmed in the UK at <a href="MGM-British%20Studios">MGM-British Studios</a> and released by <a href="MGM">MGM</a>. It was a box office success and won the <a href="Academy%20Award%20for%20Best%20Sound%20Editing">Academy Award for Best Sound Editing</a> at the <a href="40th%20Academy%20Awards">40th Academy Awards</a> in 1968. In 2001, the American Film Institute placed the film at number 65 on their <a href="100%20Years...%20100%20Thrills">100 Years... 100 Thrills</a> list.
The screenplay is based on the 1965 bestseller by <a href="E.%20M.%20Nathanson">E. M. Nathanson</a> which was inspired by a real-life WWII unit of behind-the-lines demolition specialists from the <a href="101st%20Airborne%20Division">101st Airborne Division</a> named the "<a href="Filthy%20Thirteen">Filthy Thirteen</a>".
Plot.
In March 1944, <a href="Office%20of%20Strategic%20Services">OSS</a> officer Major John Reisman is ordered by the commander of <a href="ADSEC">ADSEC</a> in Britain, Major General Sam Worden, to undertake Project Amnesty, a top-secret mission to train some of the Army's worst prisoners and turn them into commandos to be sent on a virtual suicide mission just before <a href="D-Day">D-Day</a>. The target is a <a href="ch%C3%A2teau">château</a> near <a href="Rennes">Rennes</a> where dozens of high-ranking German officers will be eliminated in order to disrupt the chain of command of the <a href="Wehrmacht">Wehrmacht</a> in Northern France before the Allied invasion. Reisman is told he can tell the prisoners that those who survive the mission will receive pardons for their crimes.
Reisman is assigned twelve convicts, all either serving lengthy sentences or destined for execution, including the slow-witted Vernon Pinkley; Robert Jefferson, an <a href="African%20American">African American</a> convicted of killing a man in a racial brawl; Samson Posey, a gentle giant who becomes enraged when pushed, convicted of accidentally killing a man who shoved him repeatedly; Joseph Wladislaw, a former officer and taciturn coal miner with the ability to speak German, convicted of killing his unit’s medic in combat; A. J. Maggott, a <a href="misogynist">misogynist</a> and religious fanatic, convicted of raping and beating a woman to death; and Victor Franko, a former member of the <a href="Chicago%20Outfit">Chicago Outfit</a> with extreme problems with authority, convicted of robbing and killing an elderly man for ten dollars. Under the supervision of Reisman and <a href="military%20police">military police</a> Sergeant Clyde Bowren, the group begins training. After being forced to construct their own living quarters, the twelve are trained in combat by Reisman and gradually learn how to operate as a group. The men further bond after Franko leads a rebellion against orders to shave in cold water, resulting in Reisman rationing hot meals and soap, earning the men the nickname "The Dirty Dozen." Captain Stuart Kinder, a psychiatrist, evaluates the men and warns Reisman that they are all mentally unstable, with Maggott being the worst of the bunch.
For parachute training the men are sent to the base operated by Colonel Everett Breed. Under strict orders to keep their mission secret, Reisman's men run afoul of Breed and his troops, especially after Pinkley poses as a general and inspects Breed's troops. Angered at the usurpation of his authority, Breed attempts to discover Reisman's mission and attempts to get the program shut down by forcing two of his men to beat a confession out of Wladislaw, who is saved by Posey and Jefferson. The convicts blame Reisman for the attack, but realize the mistake after Breed and his men arrive at their base. Reisman infiltrates his own camp and gets the convicts to disarm Breed's paratroopers, forcing Breed to leave in humiliation.
After Reisman gets prostitutes for the men to celebrate the completion of their training, Worden and his chief of staff, Brigadier General James Denton, throw the book at him. Reisman's friend, Major Max Armbruster, suggests a test of whether Reisman's men are ready: during practice maneuvers which Breed will be taking part in, the "Dirty Dozen" will attempt to capture the Colonel's headquarters. During the maneuvers, the men use various unorthodox tactics, including theft, impersonation, and rule-breaking, to infiltrate Breed's headquarters and hold him and his men at gunpoint. Impressed, Worden approves Project Amnesty.
The men are flown to France. There is a slight snag when Pedro Jimenez, one of the Dozen, breaks his neck on the jump and dies, but the others proceed with the mission. Wladislaw and Reisman infiltrate the meeting disguised as German officers while the others set up in various locations in and around the chateau. The plan falls apart when Maggott encounters a woman who had accompanied an officer, murders her and begins shooting, alerting the German officers, before Jefferson kills him. As the officers and their companions retreat to an underground bomb shelter, a firefight ensues between the Dozen and German reinforcements. Wladislaw and Reisman lock the Germans in the bomb shelter while the Dozen pry open the ventilation ducts to the shelter and drop unprimed grenades down, then pour gasoline inside. Jefferson throws primed grenades down each shaft and sprints for their vehicle, but is shot by a sniper before the grenades explode.
Reisman, Bowren and Wladislaw, the last remaining survivors of the assault team, make their escape. Back in England, a voiceover from Armbruster confirms that Worden exonerated the surviving members of the Dozen and communicated to the next of kin of the rest that "they lost their lives in the line of duty."
Production.
Writing.
Although Robert Aldrich had failed to buy the rights to E.M. Nathanson's novel "The Dirty Dozen" while it was just an outline, <a href="Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer">Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer</a> succeeded in May 1963. On publication, the novel became a best-seller in 1965. It was adapted to the screen by veteran scriptwriter and producer <a href="Nunnally%20Johnson">Nunnally Johnson</a>, and <a href="Lukas%20Heller">Lukas Heller</a>. A repeated rhyme was written into the script where the twelve actors verbally recite the details of the attack in a rhyming chant to help them remember their roles while approaching the mission target:
Casting.
The cast included many World War II US veterans including Lee Marvin, Robert Webber and Robert Ryan (<a href="US%20Marine%20Corps">US Marine Corps</a>); Telly Savalas and George Kennedy (<a href="US%20Army">US Army</a>); Charles Bronson (<a href="US%20Army%20Air%20Forces">US Army Air Forces</a>); Ernest Borgnine (<a href="US%20Navy">US Navy</a>); and Clint Walker (<a href="US%20Merchant%20Marine">US Merchant Marine</a>).
<a href="John%20Wayne">John Wayne</a> was the original choice for Reisman, but he turned down the role because he objected to the adultery present in the original script, which featured the character having a relationship with an Englishwoman whose husband was fighting on the Continent. <a href="Jack%20Palance">Jack Palance</a> refused the "Archer Maggott" role when they would not rewrite the script to make his character lose his racism; Telly Savalas took the role instead.
Six of the dozen were experienced American stars, while the "Back Six" were actors resident in the UK, Englishman <a href="Colin%20Maitland">Colin Maitland</a>, Canadians Donald Sutherland and <a href="Tom%20Busby">Tom Busby</a>, and Americans <a href="Stuart%20Cooper">Stuart Cooper</a>, <a href="Al%20Mancini">Al Mancini</a>, and <a href="Ben%20Carruthers">Ben Carruthers</a>. According to commentary on "The Dirty Dozen: 2-Disc Special Edition", when <a href="Trini%20Lopez">Trini Lopez</a> left the film early, the death scene of Lopez's character where he blew himself up with the radio tower was given to Busby (in the film, Ben Carruthers' character Glenn Gilpin is given the task of blowing up the radio tower while Busby's character Milo Vladek is shot in front of the château). Lopez's character dies off-camera during the parachute drop that begins the mission. The impersonation of the general scene was to have been done by Clint Walker, but when he thought the scene was demeaning to his character, who was a <a href="Indigenous%20peoples%20of%20the%20Americas">Native American</a>, Aldrich picked out Sutherland for the bit.
<a href="Jim%20Brown">Jim Brown</a>, the <a href="Cleveland%20Browns">Cleveland Browns</a> <a href="running%20back">running back</a>, announced his retirement from American football at age 29 during the making of the film. The owner of the Browns, <a href="Art%20Modell">Art Modell</a>, demanded Brown choose between <a href="American%20football">football</a> and acting. With Brown's considerable accomplishments in the sport (he was already the <a href="NFL">NFL</a>'s all-time leading rusher, was well ahead statistically of the second-leading rusher, and his team had won the <a href="1964%20NFL%20Championship%20Game">1964 NFL Championship</a>), he chose acting. In <a href="Spike%20Lee">Spike Lee</a>'s 2002 documentary "" Modell admitted he made a huge mistake in forcing Jim Brown to choose between football and Hollywood. He said that if he had it to do over again, he would never have made such a demand. Modell fined Jim Brown the equivalent of over $100 per day, a fine which Brown said that "today wouldn't even buy the doughnuts for a team".
Filming.
The production was filmed in UK in the summer of 1966. Interiors and set pieces took place at <a href="MGM-British%20Studios">MGM-British Studios</a>, <a href="Borehamwood">Borehamwood</a>, where the château set was built under the direction of <a href="Art%20director%23In%20film">art director</a> <a href="William%20Hutchinson%20%28art%20director%29">William Hutchinson</a>. It was wide and high, surrounded with of heather, 400 ferns, 450 shrubs, 30 spruce trees and six weeping willows. Construction of the faux château proved problematic. The script required its explosion, but it was so solid that 70 tons of explosives would have been required for the effect. Instead, a cork and plastic section was destroyed.
Exteriors were shot throughout southeast England. The credit scenes at the American military prison – alluded in the movie to be <a href="HM%20Prison%20Shepton%20Mallet">Shepton Mallett</a> – were shot in a courtyard at <a href="Ashridge">Ashridge</a> House in <a href="Hertfordshire">Hertfordshire</a>. Co-star <a href="Richard%20Jaeckel">Richard Jaeckel</a> recalled that when the introductory lineup scene was first shot, Aldrich, who liked to play pranks on his actors, initially placed Charles Bronson between Clint Walker and Donald Sutherland, which provoked an angry response from the diminutive Bronson, making Aldrich laugh.
The jump school scene was shot at the former entrance to <a href="RAF%20Hendon">RAF Hendon</a> in London. The wargame was filmed in and around the village of <a href="Aldbury">Aldbury</a>. <a href="Bradenham%2C%20Buckinghamshire">Bradenham Manor</a> was the Wargames' Headquarters. <a href="Beechwood%20Park%20School">Beechwood Park School</a> in <a href="Markyate">Markyate</a> was also used as a location during the school's summer term, where the training camp and tower were built and shot in the grounds and the village itself as parts of "<a href="Devonshire">Devonshire</a>". The main house was also used, appearing in the film as a military hospital. After filming finished, the training camp huts were relocated and used as sports equipment storage for the school's playing fields. Residents of <a href="Chenies">Chenies</a>, <a href="Buckinghamshire">Buckinghamshire</a> complained to MGM when filming caused damage around their village.
While making the film, some of the cast members gave an interview to "<a href="ABC%20Cinemas">ABC Film review</a>", in which they contrasted their own real wartime ranks to their officer roles in the film:
George Kennedy: Took me two years to make Private First Class.Lee Marvin: I didn't even make that in the Marines.Ernest Borgnine: I was beneath notice in the NavyFor punks, we're doing all right, said Marvin. I wonder how the generals are doing?
Heavy rains throughout the summer caused filming delays of several months, leading to $1 million in overruns and bringing the final cost to $5 million. Principal photography wrapped at MGM-British Studios in September 1966 with post-production to be completed at MGM studios in <a href="Culver%20City%2C%20California">Culver City, California</a>.
Release.
Theatrical.
"The Dirty Dozen" premiered at the <a href="Capitol%20Theatre%20%28New%20York%20City%29">Capitol Theatre</a> in <a href="New%20York%20City">New York City</a> on June 15, 1967 and opened at the 34th Street East theatre the following day. Despite being shot in an <a href="Aspect%20ratio%20%28image%29">aspect ratio</a> of 1.85:1, the film was initially shown in <a href="70%20mm%20film">70 mm</a> which cut off 15% of the film and resulted in a grainy look.
Reception.
Box office.
"The Dirty Dozen" was a massive commercial success. In its first five days in New York, the film grossed $103,849 from 2 theatres. Produced on a budget of $5.4 million, it earned <a href="theatrical%20rental">theatrical rental</a>s of $7.5 million in its first five weeks from 1,152 bookings and 625 prints, one of the fastest-grossing films at the time; however, on <a href="Variety%20%28magazine%29">"Variety"</a>'s weekly box office survey, based on a sample of key city theatres, it only reached number two at the U.S. box office behind "<a href="You%20Only%20Live%20Twice%20%28film%29">You Only Live Twice</a>" until it finally reached number one in its sixth week. It eventually earned rentals of $24.2 million in the United States and Canada from a gross of $45.3 million. It was the <a href="1967%20in%20film">fourth-highest-grossing film of 1967</a> and <a href="MGM">MGM</a>'s highest-grossing film of the year. It was also a hit in France, with admissions of 4,672,628.
To coincide with its release, <a href="Dell%20Comics">Dell Comics</a> published a comic "The Dirty Dozen" in October 1967.
Critical response.
The film holds an 80% rating on <a href="Rotten%20Tomatoes">Rotten Tomatoes</a> based on 50 reviews, with an average rating of 8.00/10. The critical consensus reads, "Amoral on the surface and exuding testosterone, "The Dirty Dozen" utilizes combat and its staggering cast of likable scoundrels to deliver raucous entertainment." On release, the film was criticised for its level of violence. <a href="Roger%20Ebert">Roger Ebert</a>, who was in his first year as a film reviewer for the "<a href="Chicago%20Sun-Times">Chicago Sun-Times</a>", wrote sarcastically:
I'm glad the Chicago Police Censor Board forgot about that part of the local censorship law where it says films shall not depict the burning of the human body. If you have to censor, stick to censoring sex, I say...but leave in the mutilation, leave in the sadism and by all means leave in the human beings burning to death. It's not obscene as long as they burn to death with their clothes on.
In another contemporaneous review, <a href="Bosley%20Crowther">Bosley Crowther</a> called it "an astonishingly wanton <a href="war%20film">war film</a>" and a "studied indulgence of <a href="Sadomasochism">sadism</a> that is morbid and disgusting beyond words"; he also noted:
It is not simply that this violent picture of an American military venture is based on a fictional supposition that is silly and irresponsible. ... But to have this bunch of felons a totally incorrigible lot, some of them psychopathic, and to try to make us believe that they would be committed by any American general to carry out an exceedingly important raid that a regular commando group could do with equal efficiency—and certainly with greater dependability—is downright preposterous.
Crowther called some of the portrayals "bizarre and bold":
Marvin's taut, pugnacious playing of the major ... is tough and terrifying. John Cassavetes is wormy and noxious as a psychopath condemned to death, and Telly Savalas is swinish and maniacal as a religious fanatic and sex degenerate. Charles Bronson as an alienated murderer, Richard Jaeckel as a hard-boiled military policeman, and Jim Brown as a white-hating Negro stand out in the animalistic group.
Art Murphy of "<a href="Variety%20%28magazine%29">Variety</a>" was more positive, calling it "an exciting World War II pre-D-Day drama" with an "excellent cast" and a "very good screenplay" with "a ring of authenticity to it".
The "Time Out Film Guide" notes that over the years, ""The Dirty Dozen" has taken its place alongside that other commercial classic, "<a href="The%20Magnificent%20Seven">The Magnificent Seven</a>"". The review then states:
The violence which liberal critics found so offensive has survived intact. Aldrich sets up dispensable characters with no past and no future, as Marvin reprieves a bunch of death row prisoners, forges them into a tough fighting unit, and leads them on a suicide mission into Nazi France. Apart from the values of team spirit, cudgeled by Marvin into his dropout group, Aldrich appears to be against everything: anti-military, anti-Establishment, anti-women, anti-religion, anti-culture, anti-life. Overriding such nihilism is the super-crudity of Aldrich's energy and his humour, sufficiently cynical to suggest that the whole thing is a game anyway, a spectacle that demands an audience.

Sequels, adaptations and remake.
Three years after "The Dirty Dozen" was released, "<a href="Too%20Late%20the%20Hero%20%28film%29">Too Late the Hero</a>", a film also directed by Aldrich, was described as a "kind of sequel to "The Dirty Dozen"". The 1969 Michael Caine film "<a href="Play%20Dirty">Play Dirty</a>" follows a similar theme of convicts recruited as soldiers. The 1977 Italian war film directed by <a href="Enzo%20G.%20Castellari">Enzo G. Castellari</a>, "<a href="The%20Inglorious%20Bastards">The Inglorious Bastards</a>", is a loose remake of "The Dirty Dozen". <a href="Quentin%20Tarantino">Quentin Tarantino</a>'s 2009 "<a href="Inglourious%20Basterds">Inglourious Basterds</a>" was derived from the English-language title of the Castellari film.
Several <a href="TV%20film">TV film</a>s were produced in the mid-to-late 1980s which capitalized on the popularity of the first film. Lee Marvin, Richard Jaeckel and Ernest Borgnine reprised their roles for ' in 1985, leading a group of military convicts in a mission to kill a German general who was plotting to assassinate <a href="Adolf%20Hitler">Adolf Hitler</a>. In ' (1987), Telly Savalas, who had played the role of the psychotic Maggott in the original film, assumed the different role of Major Wright, an officer who leads a group of military convicts to extract a group of German scientists who are being forced to make a deadly nerve gas. Ernest Borgnine again reprised his role of General Worden. "" (1988) depicts Savalas's Wright character and a group of renegade soldiers attempting to prevent a group of extreme German generals from starting a Fourth Reich, with <a href="Erik%20Estrada">Erik Estrada</a> co-starring and Ernest Borgnine again playing the role of General Worden. In 1988, <a href="Fox%20Broadcasting%20Company">Fox</a> aired a short-lived television series starring <a href="Ben%20Murphy">Ben Murphy</a>. Among the cast was <a href="John%20Slattery">John Slattery</a>, who played Private Leeds in eight of the show's 11 episodes.
The surviving cast members of the original film provided the voices of the toy soldiers in <a href="Joe%20Dante">Joe Dante</a>'s "<a href="Small%20Soldiers">Small Soldiers</a>".
In 2014, <a href="Warner%20Bros.">Warner Bros.</a> announced that director <a href="David%20Ayer">David Ayer</a> would be the director of a <a href="Suicide%20Squad%20%28film%29">live-action adaptation</a> of the <a href="DC%20Comics">DC Comics</a> property <a href="Suicide%20Squad">Suicide Squad</a>, and Ayer has gone on to say that the film is "the Dirty Dozen with super villains", citing the original film as inspiration. In December 2019 Warner Brothers announced it was developing a remake with David Ayer set to direct.
Historical authenticity.
Nathanson states in the prologue to his novel "The Dirty Dozen", that while he heard a legend that such a unit may have existed, he incorrectly heard they were convicts. He was unable to find any corroboration in the archives of the US Army in Europe. He instead turned his research of convicted felons into the subsequent novel. While he does not state from where he acquired the name, but Arch Whitehouse coined the name "Dirty Dozen" as the 12 enlisted men of the airborne section that would become the "Filthy Thirteen" after the lieutenant joined their ranks. In Arch Whitehouse's article in "True Magazine", he claimed all the enlisted men were full-blood Indians, but in reality only their leader, Jake McNeice was quarter Choctaw. The parts of the Filthy Thirteen story that carried over into Nathanson's book were not bathing until the jump into Normandy, their disrespect for military authority, and the pre-invasion party. The Filthy Thirteen was in actuality a demolitions section with a mission to secure bridges over the <a href="Douve">Douve</a> on D-Day.
A similarly named unit called the "<a href="Filthy%20Thirteen">Filthy Thirteen</a>" was an airborne demolition unit documented in the eponymous book, and this unit's exploits inspired the fictional account. Barbara Maloney, the daughter of John Agnew, a private in the Filthy Thirteen, told the "American Valor Quarterly" that her father felt that 30% of the film's content was historically correct, including a scene where officers are captured. Unlike the Dirty Dozen, the Filthy Thirteen were not convicts; however, they were men prone to drinking and fighting and often spent time in the stockade.
Nathanson wrote the last chapter of the novel in the form of an <a href="epistolary%20novel">epistolary novel</a>, presenting the climactic battle at the chateau in the form of a written report.
